DEBATING NATURE OF NATURE IN YELLOWSTONE 

   (The Science Times)  
(ART ADV: Map is being sent to NYT graphic clients. Non-subscribers
can make individual purchase by calling 212-556-4204 or -1927.) 
(lh) 
 By WILLIAM K. STEVENS   
 c.1998 N.Y. Times News Service   

   YELLOWSTONE NATIONAL PARK, Wyo. _ Perhaps nowhere else in the
United States outside Alaska can nature be seen at work so readily,
so completely and so authentically as in Yellowstone when the
world-famous landscape has just fully awakened from winter and is
at its vibrant best.

   On a brisk evening in late spring, with clouds enfolding
mountains still capped with snow and a setting sun gilding newly
green hillsides and meadows, a remarkable drama between predator
and prey plays out right by the roadside: A pronghorn antelope,
defending her newborn from a coyote, rushes at him fearlessly and
repeatedly. Soon she has chased him many yards away, and he gives
up.

   A bit farther along the road, again within easy sight of it, a
black bear steadily and persistently scoops ants from under a
fallen log, a casualty of one of Yellowstone's occasional fires,
and stuffs them in her mouth while her cub patiently squats on its
haunches nearby. Still farther down the road, a magnificent bull
elk, his antlers in velvet, serenely crops tender new four-inch
grass shoots, severing them with a soft ripping sound.

   It is a remarkable concentration of activity in a span of 20
minutes or so, but it is a mere hint of the bafflingly complex web
of energy transfers _ from sun to grass, grass to plant-eater,
plant-eater to predator, fire-felled tree to insect and microbe _
that define what many experts say is the most complete large
ecosystem (since wolves were re-introduced in 1995) in the
contiguous 48 states.

   But how natural is it, really? And what does it mean to be
natural, in this day and age? These questions lie at the heart of a
contentious debate over how to manage Yellowstone, and, more
broadly, over how people should relate to nature.

   The debate has crystallized around a policy known here as
natural regulation. This is the 30th anniversary of its inception,
and natural regulation has grown to encompass a broader reach than
in 1968, when it was applied more narrowly to management of the
park's famous elk population.

   Natural regulation means different things to different people.
As applied to the elk herds, it means letting the size of the herds
fluctuate naturally according to changes in climate, food supply
and pressure from predators rather than trying to manage the herds'
size by culling elk or propagating them artificially.

   To some critics of the park's management, natural regulation
means a laissez-faire, hands-off policy of letting nature take its
course, and they say it is causing much ecological damage.

   To the present Yellowstone management, natural regulation means
letting nature take its course most of the time, but intervening as
necessary to correct problems resulting from human encroachment.
``If nature is making all the right decisions, then you let nature
make the decisions,'' said John Varley, the park's chief scientist.
But ``if there is something dysfunctional caused by humankind, then
we need to go in and fix it.''

   The latter is a succinct statement of the prevailing philosophy
among conservation biologists today: Because pervasive human
activity is unavoidably altering nature, people have a
responsibility to intervene when something they do causes things to
go wrong.

   (STORY CAN END HERE. OPTIONAL MATERIAL FOLLOWS)

   nn

   INTRUSIONS ON AN ISLAND: DESPITE INTERFERENCE, SPECIES SURVIVE

   This is no less true in Yellowstone, many experts believe, even
though the park may be, as Varley says, ``as close to authentic
nature as we have in the lower 48.'' Not even magnificent
Yellowstone has escaped major effects of human impact. For this
reason, and because Yellowstone park is big (2.2 million acres) and
is under public management, advocates of natural regulation as
defined by the park managers argue that this is one of the best
places in the country to test it.

   Civilization's inroads on Yellowstone come in many varieties.
First, the park's boundaries have never enclosed the entire
ecosystem. In creating the park as the world's first national park
in 1872, Congress used the supposed boundaries of its famous
geothermal features as a guide. But the migration ranges of the
park's big animals, especially its elk, bison, wolves and bears,
extend far beyond the park. When the animals leave, they are at the
mercy of people who hunt them (in the case of elk and bison) and,
increasingly today, eliminate their habitat by development. Many of
Yellowstone's birds, like the white pelican, peregrine falcon and
numerous songbirds, migrate to the tropics and subtropics, where
they are vulnerable to a range of environmental dangers.

   Second, the park is an ecological island subject to insults from
outside.

   Many non-native species have invaded the park and continue to do
so because of accidental and purposeful introduction by people.

   Exotic plants _ even dandelions _ crowd out those native to the
park. A few years ago, an Asian disease reduced populations of
bighorn sheep in the park and throughout the West. A prolific New
Zealand snail has lately invaded the Madison and the Firehole, two
of the park's famous trout streams, threatening to overwhelm native
organisms. Whirling disease, a scourge fatal to trout by the
thousands, has infiltrated the Yellowstone region but has not been
detected in the park.

   Park managers themselves have interfered drastically with the
ecosystem in the past. First they raised elk artificially to build
up the herds after hunters in the park had severely reduced them.
Then, judging that there were too many elk, they began killing them
deliberately until a public outcry in the 1960s ended that policy
and ushered in the present era of natural regulation. The managers
also once allowed people to feed bears. By the 1920s, in an
extermination campaign, park rangers had eliminated the ecosystem's
top predator, the wolf.

   After years of work to correct these intrusions, Varley
maintains, all the major species known to live in Yellowstone when
Columbus landed in the New World live there again; it is, he says,
``the only scrap of land in the lower 48 that can make that
statement.''

   A LIGHT HAND ON THE TILLER: DETERMINING WHAT KIND OF
INTERVENTION  

   The big argument over Yellowstone involves what kind of
intervention, and how much, is necessary. The less the better, says
Michael Finley, the park superintendent, ``It's not hands-off; it's
hands lightly on the tiller.'' The reason for restraint, he says,
is that too little is known about the ecosystem's functioning to be
confident of the ultimate impact of any action. Finley paraphrases
the conservationist John Muir, ``When you go to pull one thing out
of the universe, you find it's attached to everything else.''

   In some ways, it is clear how light or heavy a touch might be
required. For instance, fires are essential to the ecosystem's
regeneration and to the creation of different habitats for
different species, and so the park managers let them burn _ unless
they threaten people and structures.

   Long ago the managers prohibited feeding the bears and closed
garbage dumps where bears foraged. Using gill nets, the managers
are clearing Yellowstone Lake of lake trout, non-natives that were
presumably introduced by fishermen, and which now threaten to
out-compete the lake's native cutthroat trout. On another front,
the managers routinely dispatch workers in what look like
spacesuits to spray non-native plants with herbicide.

   They have also adopted regulations protecting grizzly bears, a
threatened species. They have acquiesced in allowing elk to be
hunted when they leave the park in winter. This reduces the herd
and has an inevitable impact on the ecosystem. And they have
reintroduced wolves. Several packs with a total of 75 to 80 adults
and an indeterminate number of pups, possibly more than 100 wolves
in all, now roam the park.

   How bison should be treated when their winter migration takes
them outside the park remains unsettled and controversial.
Ranchers, fearing that the bison will infect their cattle with a
disease called brucellosis, insist that they be killed or returned
to the park, and until now that has been the policy.

   (STORY CAN END HERE. OPTIONAL MATERIAL FOLLOWS)

   nn

   THE ELK WARS: NATURAL REGULATION PUT TO THE TEST

   The most contentious point, however, involves the elk herd on
the park's northern range, a lovely stretch of partly open, partly
tree-covered hills and swales encompassing the Lamar and
Yellowstone river valleys. Although the northern range comprises no
more than about 10 percent of the park, its elk herd is the largest
in the world. In winter, the herd contains 10,000 to 20,000 elk. At
the end of last winter it was at a low ebb, with about 11,000 elk.

   Park managers operate on the premise that the size of the herd
fluctuates naturally, within broad limits, in response to predators
and to climate (hard winters kill many elk, as happened in 1996-97,
and drought deprives them of forage). When times are hard, the
managers say, many more elk die, and the survivors produce fewer
offspring _ the population regulates itself. So elk in the park are
simply left alone. Outside the park, about 2,000 members of the
northern herd are killed by hunters each year.

   Critics like Dr. Charles Kay, a wildlife ecologist at Utah State
University, charge that this policy has failed. Too many elk
inhabit the northern range, and they have overgrazed the land, the
critics say. Citing scientific studies, they argue that the elk
have also browsed aspen and willows to the verge of disappearance,
that the loss of these species has deprived beaver of their
principal food supply, and that a loss of willows along streams has
allowed shores to erode, degrading the streams. As a result, Kay
says, the northern range has become an ``ecological slum.''

   Kay argues that before Europeans came to Yellowstone, there were
few elk in what is now the park. The reason, he says, is that
predators contained the population. The chief or ``keystone''
predators, he says, were not wolves but American Indians, and he
advocates allowing them to hunt in the park today to control the
elk population. ``Let a band of Crow camp in there all summer and
shoot all they want,'' he says, adding that Indians kept the
ecosystem functioning for 12,000 years.

   Park officials, citing other scientific studies that they say
represent the majority opinion among scientists, say the impact of
American Indian hunting on the herds is simply unknown and that elk
always grazed the northern range (though the numbers cannot be
gauged). The weight of scientific evidence, they argue, shows that
the range is not overgrazed. One problem is the definition of
overgrazing. Park managers say that the critics expect a natural
ecosystem to look the same as one managed to produce maximum grass
for cattle. This standard, the park officials argue, is
inappropriate for a wild landscape.

   Some light might be shed on the natural regulation of elk once
the newly introduced wolves have been at work for some time.
Computer modeling has suggested that wolves might reduce the elk
population by as much as 30 percent. The wolves have specialized in
preying on elk even more than had been assumed, said Dr. Mark S.
Boyce, an ecologist formerly at the University of Wyoming and now
at the University of Wisconsin at Stevens Point, who has long
studied Yellowstone. But he said it was still too soon to gauge the
wolves' impact.

   The long-standing argument over what science says and does not
say about Yellowstone will be addressed in a congressionally
required study by the National Academy of Sciences, Varley said.
``We applaud that.''

   NATURE GOES ON: ANSWERS MAY NOT BE POSSIBLE OR RELEVANT

   But it is problematical whether the study will provide
definitive answers, and especially whether it will provide a clear
enough idea of what the pre-Columbian ecosystem was like. That may
be irrelevant anyway, not only because it is impossible to go back
but because nature, if mainstream ecologists are right, is never in
balance but rather is in a constant state of upheaval and change.
How Yellowstone would have evolved in the absence of European
colonization, according to this view, is not clear. In any case,
what has happened in the past cannot be reversed.

   Consequently, another perspective is emerging. It holds that
``even though this might not be the original nature, it is a hell
of a robust nature,'' and that while ``a lot of things have
happened, here we are today, and let's get on with it,'' says Paul
Schullery, a writer who works part-time for the park and wrote
``Searching for Yellowstone,'' a book about the park's history and
ecology (Houghton Mifflin, 1997).

   Dr. Robert Crabtree, an independent ecologist in the Yellowstone
area, contends that ``the park is too small to manage naturally.''
Varley agrees that people will always have to intervene in the
ecosystem ``to one degree or another.''

   Meanwhile the ecosystem, natural or not, churns along. Early on
a spring morning, the signs abound. Ducks dabble in ponds. Coyotes
freeze, listen, pounce on ground squirrels. The air is filled with
birdsong. Beetles go about their work underfoot. Three wolves, one
gray and two black, come down from the hills, lope across the road
only a few yards away and wade across the Lamar River, patrolling
their turf. A young grizzly, brown with gray trim, soon follows.
The hillsides are alive with elk, even though their fluctuating
population is in a trough. Bison numbers were also reduced by the
harsh 1996-97 winter. But they are there, grazing the lower levels.

   In some spots there is utter silence, broken only by the birds
and the rush of rivers and creeks, and in the crystalline air, with
rocky cliffs and forests shimmering in the distance, it is easy to
imagine that this must have been the way things were a thousand
years ago, even if in every detail they were not.

   ``People come here and they look at Yellowstone, and they go,
`My god, this is paradise,''' Crabtree said. ``But for those of us
here, we can do better as a world ecosystem. We've got problems,
but I believe they're solvable.''
